paragraphs.text:
%md
# Loan Status Predicition
 In this project, an analysis will be made of the different factors that make a loan granted to a client. And artificial intelligence algorithms will be implemented to predict whether the credit will be given or not. The data was taken from URL...  and is stored in the HDFS system.

msg.data:
Loan Status Predicition

In this project, an analysis will be made of the different factors that make a loan granted to a client. And artificial intelligence algorithms will be implemented to predict whether the credit will be given or not. The data was taken from URL… and is stored in the HDFS system.

paragraphs.text:
%md
###Load Libraries

msg.data: Load Libraries

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
sqlContext = sqlc
from pyspark.sql import functions
from pyspark.sql import Row
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession
from pyspark.ml.stat import Correlation
from pyspark.ml.feature import VectorAssembler
from pyspark.sql.functions import  avg, isnan, when, count, col,isnull
from pyspark.ml.feature import VectorAssembler,StringIndexer
from pyspark.ml.classification import LogisticRegression

%md
### Create Spark session and load files

msg.data: Create Spark session and load files

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Import SparkSession
session=SparkSession.builder.appName("Loans").getOrCreate()
sc=session.sparkContext

# Load data from HDFS as RDD
RDD_test=sc.textFile("hdfs:///user/maria_dev/Loans/Test.csv")
RDD_train=sc.textFile("hdfs:///user/maria_dev/Loans/Train.csv")

# Split lines 
RDD_test=RDD_test.map(lambda line: line.split(","))
RDD_train=RDD_train.map(lambda line: line.split(","))

# Filter the header from the data
Header=RDD_train.first()                            
RDD_train=RDD_train.filter(lambda line:line !=Header)

%pyspark
# Map the RDD to  a DataFrame

Data_Train=RDD_train.map(lambda line: Row(Loan_ID=line[0],
                                    Gender=line[1],
                                    Married=line[2],
                                    Dependents=line[3],
                                    Education=line[4],
                                    Self_Employed=line[5],
                                    ApplicantIncome=line[6],
                                    CoapplicantIncome=line[7],
                                    LoanAmount=line[8],
                                    Loan_Amount_Term=line[9],
                                    Credit_History=line[10],
                                    Property_Area=line[11],
                                    Loan_Status=line[12])).toDF()

%pyspark
Data_Train.printSchema()

msg.data:
root
 |-- ApplicantIncome: string (nullable = true)
 |-- CoapplicantIncome: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Credit_History: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Dependents: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Education: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Gender: string (nullable = true)
 |-- LoanAmount: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Loan_Amount_Term: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Loan_ID: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Loan_Status: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Married: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Property_Area: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Self_Employed: string (nullable = true)

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# All features are strings. We have to change them to a proper format

from pyspark.sql.types import *
Data_Train=Data_Train.replace("3+","3")

Data_Train=Data_Train.withColumn("ApplicantIncome", Data_Train["ApplicantIncome"].cast(FloatType())) \
   .withColumn("CoapplicantIncome", Data_Train["CoapplicantIncome"].cast(FloatType())) \
   .withColumn("Credit_History",Data_Train["Credit_History"].cast(FloatType())) \
   .withColumn("LoanAmount", Data_Train["LoanAmount"].cast(FloatType())) \
   .withColumn("Loan_Amount_Term", Data_Train["Loan_Amount_Term"].cast(FloatType())) \
   .withColumn("Dependents", Data_Train["Dependents"].cast(FloatType()))

%pyspark
# Resgister de dataFrame as a table in order to able to do sql queries
sqlContext = sqlc
Data_Train.registerTempTable("Data")

%sql
FROM Data LIMIT 10

%md
## Data Exploration
In this part, we're going to visualize and explorate different features of the data.

%md
#### Loan status for each gender

msg.data: Loan status for each gender

SELECT Gender,Loan_Status, COUNT(*) as count FROM Data GROUP BY Gender, Loan_Status

Is possible to see that men ask more for loans than women. There are nulls values inside the dataset that have to be remove or replace before making the  machine learning analysis

%md
#### Applicant Income+Coapplicant Income vs Loan Amount, classified by Loan Status

SELECT LoanAmount,Loan_Status,ApplicantIncome+CoapplicantIncome FROM Data

%md 
.
Is obvius that there is no direct relation between the amount of income and loan status. Despite of having high income there are cases where the loan was rejected. What this tell us is, that the others variables are also a decisive factor.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Empty values
In this part, we're going to find the number of missing values in the data and replace or delete them.

msg.data:
Empty values

In this part, we're going to find the number of missing values in the data and replace or delete them.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Find the total number of empty values for each column.
Data_Train.select([count(when(isnull(c), c)).alias(c) for c in Data_Train.columns])

msg.data: DataFrame[label: bigint, Urban: bigint, Semiurban: bigint, Not_Self_Employed: bigint, Female: bigint, : bigint, Not Married: bigint, Not Graduate: bigint, ApplicantIncome: bigint, CoapplicantIncome: bigint, Credit_History: bigint, Dependents: bigint, LoanAmount: bigint, Loan_Amount_Term: bigint, Loan_ID: bigint]

paragraphs.text:
%md
.
There are missing values in four columns, Credit history, Loan amount, Loan amount term and Dependents. In this case, those values are going to be replace with the average value of each column, because there is no significant amount of missing values and we don't wanna lose that information.

%md
#### Correlation matrix
Correlation matrix for four variables, Applicant income, Coapplicant income, Loan amount and Loan amount term

msg.data:
Correlation matrix

Correlation matrix for four variables, Applicant income, Coapplicant income, Loan amount and Loan amount term

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
features=["ApplicantIncome","CoapplicantIncome","LoanAmount","Loan_Amount_Term"]
vector="features"
assem=VectorAssembler(inputCols=features,outputCol=vector)
df_vector=assem.transform(Data_Train).select(vector)
mat=Correlation.corr(df_vector,vector).head()
print("Correlation matrix:\n" + str(mat[0]))

%md
There is a high correlation between Applicant income and Loan amount

msg.data: There is a high correlation between Applicant income and Loan amount

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Categorical variables.
To be able to implement machine learning algorithms is neccesary to deal with the categorical variables, because some of them are strings. We're going to converted into dummies variables.

msg.data:
Categorical variables.

To be able to implement machine learning algorithms is neccesary to deal with the categorical variables, because some of them are strings. We're going to converted into dummies variables.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
import pyspark.sql.functions as F 
categ = Data_Train.select('Education').distinct().rdd.flatMap(lambda x:x).collect()
exprs = [F.when(F.col('Education') == cat,1).otherwise(0)\
            .alias(str(cat)) for cat in categ]
Data_Train = Data_Train.select(exprs+Data_Train.columns)
Data_Train=Data_Train.drop("Graduate","Education")

categ = Data_Train.select('Married').distinct().rdd.flatMap(lambda x:x).collect()
categ1=["Not Married","MarriedD"]
exprs = [F.when(F.col('Married') == cat,1).otherwise(0)\
            .alias(str(cat1)) for cat,cat1 in zip(categ,categ1)]
Data_Train = Data_Train.select(exprs+Data_Train.columns)
Data_Train=Data_Train.drop("Married","MarriedD")


categ = Data_Train.select('Gender').distinct().rdd.flatMap(lambda x:x).collect()
exprs = [F.when(F.col('Gender') == cat,1).otherwise(0)\
            .alias(str(cat)) for cat in categ]
Data_Train = Data_Train.select(exprs+Data_Train.columns)
Data_Train=Data_Train.drop("Male","Gender")

categ = Data_Train.select('Self_Employed').distinct().rdd.flatMap(lambda x:x).collect()
categ1=["Not_Self_Employed","Self_EmployedD"]
exprs = [F.when(F.col('Self_Employed') == cat,1).otherwise(0)\
            .alias(str(cat1)) for cat,cat1 in zip(categ,categ1)]
Data_Train = Data_Train.select(exprs+Data_Train.columns)
Data_Train=Data_Train.drop("Self_Employed","Self_EmployedD")

categ = Data_Train.select('Property_Area').distinct().rdd.flatMap(lambda x:x).collect()
exprs = [F.when(F.col('Property_Area') == cat,1).otherwise(0)\
            .alias(str(cat)) for cat in categ]
Data_Train = Data_Train.select(exprs+Data_Train.columns)
Data_Train=Data_Train.drop("Rural","Property_Area")

categ = Data_Train.select('Loan_Status').distinct().rdd.flatMap(lambda x:x).collect()
categ1=["Loan_Status_Y","Loan_Status_N"]
exprs = [F.when(F.col('Loan_Status') == cat,1).otherwise(0)\
            .alias(str(cat1)) for cat,cat1 in zip(categ,categ1)]
Data_Train = Data_Train.select(exprs+Data_Train.columns)
Data_Train=Data_Train.drop("Loan_Status_N","Loan_Status")

%md
### Machine learning algorithms 
In this part, an implementation of two machine learning algorithms is going to be make for the prediction of the Loan status variable.
#### Logistic regression
Split the data in training and testing

msg.data:
Machine learning algorithms

In this part, an implementation of two machine learning algorithms is going to be make for the prediction of the Loan status variable.

Logistic regression

Split the data in training and testing

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Features for model training
features=["Urban","Semiurban","Not_Self_Employed","Female","Not Married","Not Graduate","ApplicantIncome","CoapplicantIncome","Credit_History","Dependents","LoanAmount","Loan_Amount_Term","Loan_Status_Y"]
# Transforn the features in a vector
vectorAssembler = VectorAssembler(inputCols = ["Urban","Semiurban","Not_Self_Employed","Female","Not Married","Not Graduate","ApplicantIncome","CoapplicantIncome","Credit_History","Dependents","LoanAmount","Loan_Amount_Term"], outputCol = 'features')

Data_Train = Data_Train.withColumnRenamed('Loan_Status_Y', 'label')
DataDf = vectorAssembler.transform(Data_Train)

# Select the features and the label column
DataDf = DataDf.select(['features', 'label'])

# Split the data in training and testing
splits = DataDf.randomSplit([0.7, 0.3])
train_df = splits[0]
test_df = splits[1]

# Train the model
lr = LogisticRegression(featuresCol = 'features', labelCol='label', maxIter=10)
lr = LogisticRegression( maxIter=10)
lrModel = lr.fit(train_df)
trainingSummary = lrModel.summary
print('Training set AUROC: ' + str(trainingSummary.areaUnderROC))

predictions = lrModel.transform(test_df)
predictions.select('prediction', 'probability').show(10)


# Evaluate with test data
from pyspark.ml.evaluation import BinaryClassificationEvaluator

evaluator = BinaryClassificationEvaluator()
print('Test AUROC', evaluator.evaluate(predictions))

%md 
.
For this model, a training AUROC of 0.789 and a testing AUROC of 0.771, which is a good result since the maximum value is 1. Later it will be used to evaluate the different models used.
